titlestmt.sponsor: This collection-level EAD record is a product of the Philadelphia Area Consortium of Special Collections Libraries (PACSCL) Consortial Survey Initiative, which was funded by the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: Machine-readable finding aid generated in EAD from data in the PACSCL Consortial Survey Database on 12/21/2012. Modified by Dot Porter in 2017.

bioghist.p: Andrew Cock (Cox) was a farmer and land owner who lived in Kingsess, in the County of Philadelphia in the 18th century. He was the son of Valentine Cock and brother of Otter Cox. Newesingh, or Navisink, was a piece of marshland near the Schuylkill River. The land was granted in 1669 by the Dutch governor, Peter Stuyvesant of New York to Peter Cock, and confirmed to him in 1681 by Governor Francis Lovelace (1621-1675) of New York, and reconfirmed by William Penn after his arrival.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of manuscript deeds, mortgages, indentures, receipts, and wills dating from the 17th to the 19th century. A number of the items are related to Andrew Cox (or Cock), to his father Valentine Cock and his brother Otter Cox. Of note are an inventory of land, goods, and chattel of Valentine Cock (1725); other Valentine Cock estate papers; a bond between Andrew Cock and Nicholas Scull (1728/9); and the will of Otter Cox (1744). Other materials include a 1663 deed for a parcel of land (Newesingh or Boon's Island) to Maes Hanssen; a 1672 patent, signed by Francis Lovelace; a 1826 fire insurance policy for a house at 208 High Street in the name of Catherine Regli; a fragment of a list of marriages and births of the Springer and Ferr√© families; three memorandum books of stocks bought and sold, 1863-1888; and small amount of correspondence and miscellaneous manuscripts.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

acqinfo.p: Provenance: Gift off Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin H. Barnett, 1974
